data.title: The Making of Woody Allen’s ‘Midnight in Paris’
data.meta_description: Out of a lifelong love affair with Paris, the director conjured his biggest hit and now opens up about how he did it , why he was smitten with Owen Wilson's West Coast vibe and his blissful defiance of his sister's concerns.
data.text:
City of Lights

Midnight in Paris has become director Woody Allen's top-grossing film, earning $145.2 million and bringing the longtime filmmaker new currency and serious awards season buzz. Tapping into his lifelong love affair with Paris, Allen took time to arrive at the magic story hook of what happens at the midnight hour, then got a boost when new French tax rebates made the production feasible on his modest budget.

Pictured, Owen Wilson walks along the Seine in a shot that was used in the film's Van Gogh-like poster.

STORY: Woody Allen Reveals How He Conjured Up His Biggest Hit 'Midnight in Paris'

On the Set

Woody Allen (left) and Owen Wilson discuss a scene during one of the film's many night shoots.

Allen's longtime casting director Juliet Taylor suggested Wilson for the lead role of Gil. Though not his typical on-screen alter-ego, Allen liked the idea and reworked the script to accomodate Wilson's more West coast vibe, making him a successful screenwriter.

Jokes Wilson: "He talks about me always being at the beach. I think he thinks I live at SeaWorld."

A ‘Wedding Crashers’ Reunion

Owen Wilson was happy to reunite with his Wedding Crashers co-star Rachel McAdams under Woody Allen's direction.

Allen had McAdams in mind for the role of Gil's demanding fiancee when writing the screenplay, selling her the part by telling her: "You don't want to go your whole life playing these beautiful girls. You want to play some bitchy parts. It's much more interesting for you."

Kindred Spirits

Marion Cotillard and Owen Wilson are offered suggestions by director Woody Allen.

Says Cotillard: "Woody Allen in a way found his kind of spiritual son. It was like it was meant to be. Owen fits so perfectly in Woody's universe, it was really organic and made total sense."

On Location

The production filmed both inside and on the lawns at Versailles, where Michael Sheen and Nina Arianda joined Rachel McAdams and Owen Wilson. Moving at a brisk pace, director Allen shot just 35 days over seven weeks. On the set he would frequently tell the actors to use their own words.

Says co-star Corey Stoll: "For the big group scenes, he'd figure out the traffic patterns, but then he'd want it to be messy. That was his most common direction: 'Make it messier, make it more like life.'"

Power Couple

Owen Wilson with Rachel McAdams, as they stop inside a shop.

Says Allen of his films: "I make them for the fun of making them. I work at a comparatively low budget and make the films for my own enjoyment and hope that other people like them, and it's always nice when they do."
